subject: RE: [junit] Testing API where order in which methods are invoked matters
msgSnippet: ... It s not always an option, nor is it necessarily the right thing to do. Once you have your business logic, you want to be able to test it as is , no
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Chris Dollin

> > If this object is expensive to get, it would be nice to save it
> > in-between invocations, which brings us back to maintaining state and
> > ordering methods.
>
> If this object is expensive to get, it would be nice to make
> that cheaper

It's not always an option, nor is it necessarily the right thing to do.

Once you have your business logic, you want to be able to test it "as is",
no matter how well or how bad designed it is.

At any rate, the testing framework should give you the option. You
shouldn't have to modify your production code just to accomodate the whims
of a testing framework (note that this claim is different from "write your
production code to make it as easy to test as possible").
